title.q: To the ‘Rata, or Gigantic Myrtle,’ of New Zealand

editionStmt.edition: Transcribed and edited by Philip Steer

sourceDesc.bibl: H.. To the ‘Rata, or Gigantic Myrtle,’ of New Zealand. Hawke’s Bay Herald, 15 January 1877, p. 3.

projectDesc.p: Transcribed and encoded as part of Settler Literature and Environmental Change in Australia and New Zealand," Marsden Fund Standard Grant 19-MAU-022 (Te Apārangi Royal Society of New Zealand).

lg.l: O glorious myrtle, Glorious myrtle. The northern rātā is a species of myrtle that can grow to over 40 metres high. in thy crimson robe, Crimson robe. A reference to the red flowers of the rātā.
Thou wraps’t the hills, the valleys, and the plain;
A grander picture, eye did ne’er behold,
Supreme in beauty, thou dost truly reign.
Upon the mountain top, Mountain top. The Ruahine ranges, adjacent to the settlement of Woodville, were not deforested prior to the 1870s. thou flingest wide,
Thy robust arm, to tempt the furious breeze;
But though it fall upon thee in its might,
Unharmed thou stands’t, a very king of trees.
When now, the scorching perpendicular rays
Of summer suns do bid us seek the shade;
Where can we find a lovelier retreat
Than neath thee? monarch of the forest glade.
Sweet there to watch the tui Tui. The tui is a species of bird that feeds on nectar and is known for its melodious song. dip his bill,
Into the deep recesses of thy flowers,
And sip the honied nectar to his fill,
Then warble forth sweet melodies for hours.
And were I now about to lead my love
Unto the altar, where we might be wed;
A myrtle spray among the daisies twined,
Should be the bridal wreath upon her head.
When, at the last, I lay me down to die,
And loved ones seek to decorate my clay,
While on my bier the snow white lilies lie,
Among them let there be a myrtle spray.

body.p: H. H. An editorial comment in the issue of the newspaper where the poem was published identifies the author as Stephen Hutching. Hutching and his family arrived in the area in 1875.
Woodville, January 4, 1877. Woodville … 1877. Woodville, in the southern Hawke’s Bay region of the North Island, was established in the 1870s as a centre of timber milling.
